Package com.taco.suit_lady.util.tools

Class TaskTools

java.lang.Object
com.taco.suit_lady.util.tools.Exe
public class TaskTools extends Object
Contains utility methods related to threading, including synchronization.

It is recommended that you only use this class if you are experienced with synchronization.

    • start

      public static Thread start​(Thread thread)

    • start

    • start

      public static Thread start​(Supplier<Runnable> threadSupplier)
      Creates and then starts a Thread using the specified Supplier.

      If the Runnable returned by the specified Supplier is itself a Thread, no additional Thread will be created.

      Parameters:
      threadSupplier - The Supplier that returns the Runnable that is to be created as a Thread.
      Returns:
      The Thread returned by the specified Supplier.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if the specified Supplier is null.

    • sync

      @SafeVarargs public static void sync​(Lock lock, Runnable runnable, Consumer<Throwable>... onFinallyActions)

      Synchronizes the execution of the specified Runnable.

      Example Usage

       String s = ThreadTools.run(lock, ()-> sampleObject.sampleAction());
      Parameters:
      lock - The Lock being used for synchronization.
      runnable - The Runnable that is executed synchronously using the specified ReentrantLock.
      onFinallyActions - Actions that are executed asynchronously upon the end of this method.
      • Actions are executed in a finally block, guaranteeing execution (unless runnable is null).
      • An Exception (or any Throwable) thrown during the execution of an action will be passed as the parameter of each action.
      • Actions will be executed before the lock is unlocked.
      • If an Exception is thrown during the execution of an action, remaining actions will not be executed.
      • Null actions are ignored.
      See Also:
      sync(Lock, Function, Supplier, boolean, Consumer...)

    • sync

      @SafeVarargs public static void sync​(Lock lock, Runnable runnable, boolean allowNull, Consumer<Throwable>... onFinallyActions)

      Synchronizes the execution of the specified Runnable.


      Example Usage

       String s = ThreadTools.run(lock, ()-> sampleObject.sampleAction(), true);
      Parameters:
      lock - The ReentrantLock being used for synchronization.
      runnable - The Runnable that is executed synchronously using the specified ReentrantLock.
      allowNull - Determines what to do when the specified ReentrantLock is null.
      1. When true: Executes the specified Runnable asynchronously.
      2. When false: Throws a NullPointerException.
      onFinallyActions - Actions that are executed asynchronously upon the end of this method.
      • Actions are executed in a finally block, guaranteeing execution (unless runnable is null).
      • An Exception (or any Throwable) thrown during the execution of an action will be passed as the parameter of each action.
      • Actions will be executed before the lock is unlocked.
      • If an Exception is thrown during the execution of an action, remaining actions will not be executed.
      • Null actions are ignored.
      See Also:
      sync(Lock, Function, Supplier, boolean, Consumer...)

    • sync

      @SafeVarargs public static <R> R sync​(Lock lock, Supplier<R> runnableSupplier, Consumer<Throwable>... onFinallyActions)

      Synchronizes the execution of the specified Supplier.

      Example Usage

       String s = ThreadTools.run(lock, ()-> sampleObject.calculateName(), true);
      Type Parameters:
      R - The type of Object returned by this method (and the specified Supplier.
      Parameters:
      lock - The ReentrantLock being used for synchronization.
      runnableSupplier - The Supplier that is executed synchronously using the specified ReentrantLock.
      onFinallyActions - Actions that are executed asynchronously upon the end of this method.
      • Actions are executed in a finally block, guaranteeing execution (unless runnableSupplier is null).
      • An Exception (or any Throwable) thrown during the execution of an action will be passed as the parameter of each action.
      • Actions will be executed before the lock is unlocked.
      • If an Exception is thrown during the execution of an action, remaining actions will not be executed.
      • Null actions are ignored.
      Returns:
      The value returned by the specified Supplier.
      See Also:
      sync(Lock, Function, Supplier, boolean, Consumer...)

    • sync

      @SafeVarargs public static <R> R sync​(Lock lock, Supplier<R> runnableSupplier, boolean allowNull, Consumer<Throwable>... onFinallyActions)
      Synchronizes the execution of the specified Supplier.

      Example Usage: 

       String s = ThreadTools.run(lock, ()-> sampleObject.calculateName(), true);
      Type Parameters:
      R - The type of Object returned by this method (and the specified Supplier.
      Parameters:
      lock - The ReentrantLock being used for synchronization.
      runnableSupplier - The Supplier that is executed synchronously using the specified ReentrantLock.
      allowNull - Determines what to do when the specified ReentrantLock is null.
      1. When true: Executes the specified Supplier asynchronously.
      2. When false: Throws a NullPointerException.
      onFinallyActions - Actions that are executed asynchronously upon the end of this method.
      • Actions are executed in a finally block, guaranteeing execution (unless runnableSupplier is null).
      • An Exception (or any Throwable) thrown during the execution of an action will be passed as the parameter of each action.
      • Actions will be executed before the lock is unlocked.
      • If an Exception is thrown during the execution of an action, remaining actions will not be executed.
      • Null actions are ignored.
      Returns:
      The value returned by the specified Supplier.
      See Also:
      sync(Lock, Function, Supplier, boolean, Consumer...)

    • sync

      @SafeVarargs public static <T,​ R> R sync​(Lock lock, Function<T,​R> runnableFunction, Supplier<T> functionInputSupplier, boolean allowNullLock, Consumer<Throwable>... onFinally)
      Synchronizes the execution of the specified runnableFunction using the value returned by the specified functionInputSupplier as the function's input.

      Note That...

      1. If the onFinally array is not empty, any thrown Exception is expected to be handled by the specified onFinally array.
      2. If the onFinally array is empty, any Exception thrown during the execution of the specified Supplier will be internally caught and re-thrown.

      Example Usage 

       public static double distanceToCursor(Point2D point) {
      ExceptionTools.check(point, "Point cannot be null.");
      return ThreadTools.run(new ReentrantLock(), paramPoint-> point.distanceTo(paramPoint), ()-> Mouse.getLocation(), true);
 }
      Type Parameters:
      R - The type of Object returned by this method (and the specified Function.
      Parameters:
      lock - The ReentrantLock being used for synchronization.
      runnableFunction - The Function that is executed synchronously using the specified ReentrantLock.
      functionInputSupplier - The Supplier is used to supply the parameter for the Function.
      allowNullLock - Determines what to do when the specified ReentrantLock is null.
      1. When true: Executes the specified Function asynchronously.
      2. When false: Throws a NullPointerException.
      onFinally - Actions that are executed asynchronously upon the end of this method.
      1. Actions are executed in a finally block, guaranteeing execution (unless runnableFunction or functionInputSupplier is null).
      2. An Exception (or any Throwable) thrown during the execution of an action will be passed as the parameter of each action.
      3. Actions will be executed before the lock is unlocked.
      4. If an Exception is thrown during the execution of an action, remaining actions will not be executed.
      5. Any null actions will result in a NullPointerException being thrown.
      Returns:
      The value returned by the specified runnableFunction.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If...
      1. The specified lock is null and allowNullLock is specified as false.
      2. The specified runnableFunction is null.
      3. The specified functionInputSupplier is null.
      4. The specified onFinally array is null.
      5. Any of the elements within the onFinally array is null.

      All null-checks are performed at the beginning of the method.

    • lock

      public static void lock​(Lock lock)
      Locks the specified ReentrantLock.
      Throws a NullPointerException if the specified ReentrantLock is null.

      Calling this method is the same as calling ThreadTools.lock(lock, false)

      Parameters:
      lock - The ReentrantLock.
      See Also:
      sync(Lock, Function, Supplier, boolean, Consumer...)

    • lock

      public static boolean lock​(Lock lock, boolean allowNull)

      Locks the specified ReentrantLock.

      If this method returns true, Lock.unlock() must be called afterwards.

      Example Usage

       //If lock is null and allowNull is false, this will throw a NullPointerException.
 if (ThreadTools.lock(lock, allowNull)) {
      //Use a try-finally block to ensure that the ReentrantLock is always unlocked}.
      try {
          //Synchronized code
      } finally {
          ThreadTools.unlock(lock);
      }
 //Only executed when allowNull is true (a NullPointerException will have already been thrown).
 } else {
      //On-fail code - executed when lock is null.
 }
      Generally speaking, it is a good idea to use a sync method instead of manually locking and unlocking.
      Parameters:
      lock - The ReentrantLock being locked.
      allowNull - Determines what to do when the specified ReentrantLock is null.
      1. When true: Returns false immediately; does not perform any synchronization.
      2. When false: Throws a NullPointerException.
      Returns:
      True if the lock was successful, false otherwise.
      See Also:
      sync(Lock, Function, Supplier, boolean, Consumer...)
